resources.string: Vowel phonation analysis\nModel is sensitive to microphone quality, requires good hardware
Please record a short speech fragment. Speak clearly and naturally for 5-30 seconds.

Breathe in as deeply as possible, start recording. Pronounce a vowel (a, o, u, e, i) as steadily as possible until your lungs are empty, then stop recording and run analysis.\n\n Repeat analysis is recommended after 30 seconds. For repeat analysis, pronounce the vowel for 5 seconds.

No description available for this characteristic.
Local jitter — short-term instability of fundamental frequency (F0). Reflects micro-fluctuations in voice pitch from period to period. Elevated values may indicate voice tremor.
Absolute jitter — absolute difference between adjacent fundamental frequency periods. Measure of irregularity of vocal fold oscillations over time.
Jitter PPQ5 — measure of fundamental frequency stability averaged over five periods. Used to assess voice tremor.
PPE (Pitch Period Entropy) — entropy of fundamental frequency period. Characterizes irregularity and unpredictability of vocal fold oscillations.
Shimmer APQ11 — amplitude instability of voice averaged over 11 periods. Reflects volume change from cycle to cycle.
Shimmer APQ3 — amplitude instability of voice over three periods. Shows short-term amplitude fluctuations.
Shimmer (dB) — amplitude variation of voice in decibels. High values may indicate volume instability.
Local shimmer — short-term amplitude instability. Reflects volume change between adjacent periods.
HNR (Harmonics-to-Noise Ratio) — ratio of harmonic energy to noise in voice. Characterizes voice clarity and sonority; decrease may indicate hoarseness.
F1 — first formant. First peak in vowel spectrum, related to tongue position and height.
F2 — second formant. Second peak in vowel spectrum, related to tongue front-back position and vowel articulation.
F0 range — difference between maximum and minimum fundamental frequency in recording. Reflects voice pitch mobility.
Intensity range — difference between maximum and minimum volume in recording. Reflects voice volume dynamics.

About

The app is intended for preliminary analysis of speech features that may indicate Parkinson's disease using machine learning algorithms. This app is not a medical device and is not intended for diagnosis. Results must not be used for treatment decisions. If in doubt, consult a physician. For the most accurate results, it is recommended to record speech in a quiet environment using a quality microphone.

Models

Model accuracy was determined by 10-fold cross-validation. The vowel phonation model has accuracy 80.76% ± 9.66% and was trained on 496 recordings (24 PD patients, 22 healthy). The speech model has accuracy 96.53% ± 1.18% and was trained on 22582 recordings (441 PD patients, 286 healthy).
